content.description:
Question refers to the excerpt below.

Women’s libbers do not speak for the majority of American women. American women do not want to be liberated from husbands and children. We do not want to trade our birthright of the special privileges of American women—for the mess of pottage called the Equal Rights Amendment.

“Modern technology and opportunity have not discovered any nobler or more satisfying or more creative career for a woman than marriage and motherhood. The wonderful advantage that American women have is that we can have all the rewards of that number-one career, and still moonlight with a second one to suit our intellectual, cultural, or financial tastes or needs.”

Phyllis Schlafly, “What’s Wrong with ‘Equal Rights’ for Women?,” 1972
content.question: The ideas in the excerpt about women’s roles in society have the most in common with ideas associated with which of the following?

choices.label: Activism on behalf of women’s rights during the middle of the nineteenth century
The greater separation of home and workplace during the first decades of the nineteenth century
Political and social reform efforts led by women’s clubs during the late nineteenth century
The increased participation of women in the workforce during the Second World War

content.answer: The greater separation of home and workplace during the first decades of the nineteenth century

skill.text: Skill 5.A: Identify patterns among or connections between historical developments and processes.
